Finished playing this new "Walking Dead" game twice and now on my 3rd attempt. Ordered this game through Amazon and it was delivered rather quickly, especially since there was the threat of a winter storm heading my way. Amazon kept me updated on any changes made in release date, deliver time due to storms, and price.

Anyway, this version of the "Walking Dead" is LIGHT YEARS ahead of that other game by the same name - you know the one I'm talking about that just about everyone rated 5 stars but somehow this games gets quite a few 1 stars or 2 stars. This game actually lived up to my expectations and I am very pleased with the game play. That other game S-T-U-N-K!!!

You play the role of Daryl Dixon from the TV show "The Walking Dead" and you are on an adventure in search of your brother, Merle, and to find an evacuation point in Atlanta, GA. Along the way, you have to search/scavenge for various items in order to survive. Some items are: food, sports drinks, various weapons, ammo, fuel, etc. Also, there are some relics/artifacts that you need to find in order to open up various strengths/weapons if you so decide to play the game numerous times. You also pick up survivors and can send them out on missions in search of survival gear. You need to also have a vehicle large enough to carry all you supplies/weapons and survivors  - if vehicle not large enough you then need to choose what stays behind and what other survivor you must drop in order to continue mission. There were many times when I had to leave quite a few survivors behind for I did not have the proper sized vehicle for everyone.

After reading numerous other reviews about this particular "Walking Dead" game, got to agree with some that said that the graphics are not the highest in quality (better than that other game), the zombies are a bit too cartoonish (more believable than that other game), people get tired of searching the same looking structures (at least you know where all the "goodies" are hidden for they are always in the same spots), and a bunch of other things. Anyone else ever notice that some of the zombies in this game ACTUALLY look like some of the characters from the TV show????? Or is that just me???? Probably just me.

Read some reviews where people were a bit disappointed about when you sneak up on a zombie with some type of a weapon in their hands in order to kill said zombie, that they get frustrated that the game automatically reverts to Daryl's knife for the kill. I, too, thought that that was a bit silly but quickly realized why - if you are bashing the head of a zombie with a lead pipe, baseball bat, hammer, or something else THERE IS ACTUALLY A LOUD ENOUGH NOISE MADE THAT ACTUALLY ATTRACTS OTHER ZOMBIES!!!!!!!! Found that out the hard way. I, too, like to sneak up on a zombie and bashed their head in with my trusty baseball bat (my favorite) but it sounds like you are smacking a watermelon when you hit the zombies head. Other zombies nearby hear that and come a charging. Once you open up the relic that gives you the crossbow at the very beginning of the game, the problem of sneaking up on zombies will be remedied. Yep - the crossbow is the best weapon of all, so is the silenced rifle and pistol but ammo for those weapons are scarce.

I like how when you re-start the game, you have the option of choosing alternate routes that you ignored the first time and meet new survivors. Fighting in the sawmill, the hospital, and the chemical lab were about the most brutal levels of the game. However, that final mission will kick your butt - 1st time I played the final mission it took me about 5 actual hours to figure out and suffered numerous deaths. Suggest you find some grenades for this level for they will help immeasurably. Now, can somewhat quickly make it through. I also like how you are able to chop the heads or limbs off of the zombies with certain bladed weapons - took me a while to figure that out. Now I am able to send heads flying through the air in glee (but sometimes do get too excited and do forget about that zombie coming up behind me).

A few things that I found annoying/do not like about this game: When you shoot a crossbow bolt and it goes just beyond reach of the playing field (i.e. - crossbow bolt is just beyond a fence and you can see it but are unable to retrieve it). Another thing that I thought annoying is when I go through a room; totally clear the room of potential zombies; thoroughly search the room; close every door possible; and still do a thorough search, there suddenly is a "mysterious" zombie standing right next to my character!!!! How did it get there and where did it come from!!!! That baffles me!! The zombie patrols are a bit of a nuisance for, when I'm trying to sneak up on one they always seem to be able to turn on me just in time to face me (not always though). The grappling is a bit troublesome especially when there are 5 or 6 zombies standing in line patiently waiting their turn to chomp on me - thought that rotating circle was a bit annoying until I remembered that similar non-sense you got to go through in "Dead Island". Also thought that the zombies "hearing" is quite ultra-sensitive to gunfire - if you plan to fire a weapon, be prepared to run for every zombie in the area is coming after you!!

I have a bad habit of trying to slaughter as many zombies as possible - being stealthy actually does work in most instances. Trying to be stealthy when there are 30+ zombies in the area is not going to work very well - learned that the hard way numerous times. My natural instinct is to eliminate as many zombies as possible so that my escape routes are open. Had to quickly learn the value of stealth and ignore chasing after zombies.

All in all, I thought that this game was very good. Yeah, some minor nit-picky issues; graphics not as awesome that everyone wants; re-play value is definitely there for you can go back and explore ignored areas. The game was what I was hoping for (unlike that "other" game). Only reason I gave this game 4 stars was because I am unable to give 3.5 stars - do think that this game is above 3 stars but below 4 stars. Again, Amazon done a great job getting this game to me in a timely manner!!!!!!!!!!!!
summary: WAAAYYYY better than that "other" game of the same title!!!

reviewText: Item is as described.
the game is pretty good and i got it fro someone who couldn't find it at the time.

The Good: Amazing new graphics engine, battle ambiance is very realistic sounding, story is decent, campaign nails atmosphere, lots of guns to use, multiplayer is a blast with the new deathmatch mode, maps are designed superbly

The Bad: Campaign doesn't have many intense scripted moments, campaign can be very hard most of the time, requires a completely new rig to run on ultra settings

So the military shooters march on and seem to bring with them new multiplayer ideas, updated graphics, and at least trying to make more realistic and more tense single player campaigns. Battlefield 3 drops the Bad Company name and picks up off the original name. It has nothing to do with BF2 or that line in the series, but keeps the Bad Company multiplayer, so it mixes it up a bit. BF3's single player mode gives you a taste of the new graphics engine, Frostbite 2, as well as a chance to test out some guns. The story is actually interesting with a couple of plot twists but nothing sophisticated. You jump around different people trying to find a portable nuke that was stolen. You go from the Middle East, to Russia, to a few other parts of the world, and BF3 tries throwing a few new things out there.

The characters are good and the voice acting is great, but you won't get much out of a military single player campaign. The campaign nails the atmosphere with lots of explosions, the excellent Battlefield ambiance is back and sounds more realistic than ever thanks to the new engine. The campaign does lack the scripted cinematic set pieces we grow to enjoy in these types of games. There are a few such as the earthquake in Iraq, the beginning train scene, and the jet scene in the middle of the game, but the rest is just running a gunning through open terrain and buildings. The pacing is good, but I wanted more action and some more scripted sets to make the campaign feel more punchy. BF3 does add some detail that other military shooters haven't done such as great animations. One scene has a Russian jet shooting your squad down. Running from cover to cover and ducking shows your character sliding into cover and falling down like you actually would if you dived. Getting up is just as great to look at because you stumble out of being prone so it feels so real and awesome.

The graphics are probably some of the best ever seen so far. Being on the PC the game is DirectX11 only so you get just some amazing lighting, excellent looking textures, and the most realistic water I have ever seen. The lights and coronas off the sun and flashlights blind you, everything reflects like it would in real life. Plus the sound is amazing and is actually useful in multiplayer because distance makes a difference in sound here. Gun fire sounds different at different ranges rather than just quieter. Bullets whip and whizz past you with realistic sounds, gun fire sounds incredible and the explosions look too real. The game does require a seriously (like within the last year) powerful rig to run because there's no DirectX9 option here.

While the graphics are really the only major thing going for the campaign it is nice to play and has some replay value just to look at everything alone. The difficulty is all over the place and some spots are just extremely tough and you can die very quickly in this game. This isn't a run and gun arcade shooter like Modern Warfare or other military shooters. My only other complaint is that the game doesn't recognize gamepads very well even the Xbox 360 controller which most games have built-in standard. I did notice the mouse and keyboard felt better because it seems the game was built around these controls.

The multiplayer is where the money's at and BF3 delivers with new modes and some great maps. Using EA's Origin client you get a browser-based experience with filters and all the greatness of using a PC. The new mode is deathmatch which is greatly welcomed and back are Rush and Conquest. This time you get to play on large maps which can hold 64 players and it really does feel like a battlefield. The new maps are great and deathmatch is addictive, but DICE refined the unlock system. You don't get perks, but you do get to add things to your loadout like infinite sprint, defibrillators, medpacks etc. It does take a long time to start unlocking good stuff and you're stuck with crappy loadouts. Weapons have no scopes (except the sniper rifle), plus you only get one main weapon per class to start with. Be patient and wait to unlock scopes for rifles, stick to close range combat and just tough it out.

Using vehicles is back, and standard, on Rush and Conquest, and while these remain the same, they never get old. The new engine helps make the online fights feel bigger and badder with the sound coming into play, plus shooting down boats and helicopters with 4 guys in a tank never gets old. I didn't find any stability issues and EA is constantly updating Origin and the browser experience for online play so just stick with it and enjoy them. Battlefield 3 may not deliver a riveting single player, but the new engine, and excellent multiplayer will keep you hooked. You can also jump in for a co-op campaign ride, but you will come back for the multiplayer thanks to the, slow, yet steady unlocks which make you feel like you truly earned them.
summary: Excellent sequel with a gorgeous graphics engine

reviewText:
There are some things that I review where I simply can't describe why I like them. I just do. It may be a certain trait that just plays right into an interest of mine, or an original concept that I particularly jive on. But sometimes, even that's not the case. There's no fathomable reason why I should love this thing as much as I do, yet I go and sing its praises to anybody who will listen. And so, I can't really explain why I love "Tomodachi Life" as much as I do. But I suspect the ability to make anime icon Lupin III and Hillary Clinton get hitched, or have Hank Hill and Sadako of "The Ring" infamy be best buddies might have something to do with it.

"Tomodachi Life" has absolutely no plot, and to an extent, absolutely no point whatsoever. You might think of it as "The Sims," but played with Miis and done in the style of a particularly abstract Andy Kaufman gag. You either import Miis from your 3DS, create your own in-game, scan them in, or use a friend's, then put them on an island that you name. Oh, yes, that's after you customize their voice and personality. After that, you set them loose to interact with each other, solving their crises, aiding their relationships, and occasionally taking a peek into their dreams. Which sometimes involve them in humorous "Sailor Moon" fantasies. Or dancing and chanting in a very cult-like fashion around a miscellaneous household item. Yep.

Honestly, there isn't much in the way of real, engaging gameplay, but to me, that's what makes it such a fresh experience. There are no convoluted menus. No annoying menial tasks that might take 20 minutes at a time to do. Nothing like that. "Tomodachi Life" is, to an extent, a life simulator for people who hate life simulators. Everything is handled with a few clicks of the touch screen, and you can either play for five minutes at a time or fifty minutes at a time. Yes, sometimes, things will repeat. A Mii will have the same dream, or a line of dialogue will be uttered twice. But having been played at a very dedicated rate for over two weeks now, I can wholeheartedly say that I am seeing new and unique things everyday still. To top it off, my partner has the game as well, and her experience has been almost entirely different from my own. To me, that speaks volumes to the quality of the game. No one copy will progress or act in the exact same way, which is more than I can say for Nintendo's other major life simulator, "Animal Crossing," despite being a very big fan of that as well.

But what do you do outside of creating Miis and paying attention to their needs? You'll definitely be shopping for them, whether it be hats, clothes, outlandish costumes, food, or new decorations for their rooms, which contribute to their RPG-like "Happiness Level." Outside of that, you can check in on them in a restaurant, send them on an 8-bit role-playing quest, watch two lovebirds chase each other down the beach, or peek in on an outdoor barbecue party. My personal favorite side-activity, and one which can certainly become a time sink if you let it, is at the concert hall. Choosing from a nice variety of musical choices, you can make Miis sing as a solo act, a duo, or a group. Best part is? You get to write the lyrics to any song and hear them sing it. They can be silly, funny, or (if you work around the censored words list, which is pretty easy) a veritable cornucopia of nonsensical raunch. This is just one of the many activities in "Tomodachi Life" that may seem like a silly diversion, but can quite easily keep you engaged for far longer than it should.

That's something that could be said for the entire experience, though. "Tomodachi Life" might not be the most in-depth, realistic life simulator out there, but I don't think it's trying to be. If "The Sims" is the most painstaking, and "Animal Crossing" the lighthearted equivalent, then this is the out-of-left-field, completely off-the-rails festival of unmitigated silliness that people who just want a good laugh play. It's fun by yourself, and it's fun playing side-by-side with a friend, trading Miis and watching them interact with each other's islanders. There's no huge commitment, and you can play it every day, or quit for a month then come back to it. Honestly, this is the type of life simulator I've been waiting for, and it's the type of bizarre, risky game that I've wanted to see Nintendo make more of. Abstract in its humor, novel in its execution, this is something that I can't help but love every second of.

So, like I said above, at the beginning of this admittedly short review, "Tomodachi Life" is something that I can't necessarily put into words. Simply put, it's just fun, funny, and most importantly, fresh. There's nothing else on the market quite like this. Any person of any age, I think, could have a blast with this. While I do think it would be nice if same-sex relationships were included, and that the default "player hand" that shows up sometimes could have its race customized (because, y'know, not everyone has pale skin,) I still think this is, all-in-all, a very wonderful and unique experience that almost anybody could have a total blast with.

I mean, c'mon. Where else are you going to watch Duke Nukem become the most desired man on an island? Or watch yourself get into a committed relationship with a dreadheaded goth? Or see Danny Trejo role around on the floor in a sweatsuit out of boredom? Yeah. I rest my case.

Pros:

- A unique idea executed well.
- Loads of content, and most of it is fun.
- One of the funniest games on the market.

Cons:

- Lack of same-sex relationships sucks for those aren't straight.
- Occasional repetition.

Grade: 9 (Bomber)
summary: Absence of Sense, But Not of Fun

reviewText:
This game is amazingly fun. All sorts of tricks are avail to do and excellent graphics. LOVE IT! <3

Only 1 issue with the game itself, the cheat codes won't work for me. I have tried everything I know. I did some research and evidently for this 360 game, the cheat codes cannot be used. If they can be, I have not found a way to make them work.

Trust me, if Amazon would give me the option to rate an item 10 stars, this game would absolutely get it!
We start the game exactly where we left off in GOW2. The war between the Titans and The Gods is about to begin and Kratos (you) is in the middle of it.
The intro, is by far, the best intro in the history of videogames. I don't want to spoil you anything, but I can tell you that, by the time you finish the intro scene, you will feel like you just want more and more!!!
the game is sooooo EPIC!! The boss fights don't disappoint. they are incredibly dynamic. All the Greek gods will give you a different challenge and make you change the way you fight. each boss requires you to rethink your plan of attack.
The gameplay in general will feel almost the same as GOW2 but refined. You have better weapons, and a great arsenal to defend yourself against the armies of the Gods.
The quick time events in this game feel very differently from the previous entries. Whereas in the past games the button you had to press at the quick time event appeared in the middle of the screen, now this game offers a better style. The buttons will appear on the side of the screen according to the same layout as the ps3 Dualshock controller. For example, in the controller, the button "X' is located at the bottom. So, anytime you have to press "X", in the screen, you will see the button signal at the bottom of the screen. This was a change for the good, for now, everytime you are in the middle of the action fighting an enemy or boss, the action won't be interrupted by the button in  the middle of the screen like in the past games. You will enjoy this new change.
The graphics are gorgeous. The environments and the enemies look amazing. I specially enjoyed the design of the very first boss ------(spoiler).
The smaller enemies, usually won't give you much of a challenge, but sometimes these enemies will group and attack at the same time. Be careful, specially when fighting many of these and also a sub-boss for the smaller enemies will i=hold you and the sub-boss will attack you, causing good damaged to you.
Another good mechanic that I enjoyed was the "block and counter" (not sure what's the word for that..sorry) that we first found in the previous game. It feels really rewarding when you block at the last minute and blasting a devastating counter attack thanks to the golden fleece. (I personally loved to used this i n GOW2).
The story of revenge of Kratos is a good story..kinda. But still makes the game enjoyable. You will feel Krato detemination like never before. At one point in the game, Kratos will meet a special person to which he actually bonds. And you can feel the bond very natural. This will show you that Kratos is not just a killing machine..and remind you that once, he was actually a family man.
The soundtrack of the game does not disappoint. It couldn't have been better. Is epic and will inspire you to keep kicking some godly a$$e$. The great variation that the composers, Gerard Marino, Jeff Rona, Mike Reagan, Ron Fish and Cris Velasco provide is b y far their best job. My personal favorite is the song that plays at the final fight called "Brothers of Blood".
The game is the best in the saga. i wish this game would have been the last, it would have been the perfect closing for this epic saga. But unfortunately, Sony Santa Monica though it would be a great idea to make yet another GOW game..the "Ascension" one...which is not, by any means, bad..but just saying this game was perfect for closing the saga. You can read my review of the other game in my channel/profile.
All in all, don't miss this game. You will regret it. Specially if you are a die hard fan of the GOW saga like me.
summary: The perfect closing for the GOW saga. If I could give an item 10 stars, this game would totally get it!!!

reviewText:
I really enjoyed the Force Unleashed despite all of its flaws. What the game lacked in polish, it made up for in a storyline that I really enjoyed.

Fast forward to the Force Unleashed II. Most of the control issues have been fixed. A lot of the graphical hiccups have been adjusted as well. The game looks and plays very well, but not great - no wear near the level of a game like God of War III. The force powers have been upgraded, dual lightsabers look great and sith fury is just awesome. The targeting system has been vastly upgraded, so there is less blasting plants or walls when you are trying to hit an enemy. At the same time, you still get trapped in your animations and can be carried away from enemies or off of ledges. Even with those gripes, there is far more polish here than on the original.

Unfortunately, the story is sadly lacking. Where I was compelled to see what happened, excited to see familiar faces and square off with The Emperor; here it was just kind of...meh.

Many of the reviews claim the game can be completed in 5-6 hours. That is true, on easy, not completing many of the "tasks" to fully complete the game. That said; if you're not into trophy collections and collecting various items for your costume, combos, etc., Force Unleashed II is probably a rental. If you enjoy playing through several times to get every last dime out of your purchase and don't mind waiting for the inevitable DLC or must own all things Star Wars, than this is a nice addition to the catalogue. Good, not great, wholly unremarkable.

reviewText: I bought this game about 2 months ago. I was a Warcraft player but then I heard that they made a Warhammer game and got it. If you have ever played Warcraft you know the pains of being ganked by level 70 players at level 6. In Warhammer there is no ganking and the game is a lot less cartoony, it really feels like war. No more saving up your whole life for a mount in Warhammer they are cheaper and its easier to save up. one of the down sides is that there a lot less professions: no fishing, no blacksmithing, no mining, only trinket making, salvaging ruined equipment, butchering [not to be confused with cooking], alchemy, growing plants from seeds, and scavenging. One downside is that being new there are new patches all the time. I read one review that said all the classes are alike well thats not true all the classes have their own abilities, specialties, and looks [who can say the floating magus and the red, spike haired bright wizard are alike]. Overall this a lot like a serious Warcraft.
summary: A Warcraft turned Warhammer players review.

reviewText:
As Need For Speed games go, I must say....this is the poorest installment.

I'm a racing game fanatic, and have always been a fan of the Need For Speed series, but this one is mightily flawed.

The graphics are average at best, but the videos and information on each of the cars was superb. The graphics and frame rate take a major hit when you go really fast, and actually, the cars at times don't even feel like they're on the ground when driving.

The cars control just okay....but on the more difficult tracks, it is really hard to keep up with the leaders of the pack because it isn't really that easy to take hard turns and hairpins all perfectly like the computer always does.

Being able to drive a Ford GT90 and my dream car, the Jaguar XJ220, is what made me buy this game, but then being able to use them in the game made me really wonder if they should even be dream cars.

Look to Gran Turismo 2 if you want a better selection of excotic cars that are actually controllable.

The sounds of the game are just so-so....all the cars seemingly sound alike when accelerating....and you'll get used to the grating metal sound of nailing walls at high speeds....

The best aspect of this game is the music, quite possibly the best of the NFS series, but when you buy a racing game for the music....that's pretty pathetic.

If you're a fan of the NFS series and HAVE to have every NFS out there, sure, pick this one up for a very cheap price. It's not worth more than 4 or 5 bucks nowadays, so don't pay any more than that.

Die-hard racing fans? Look elsewhere.

Overall, 5 out of 10.
summary: Someone was drunk while designing this one....

reviewText: Glad I got it.

With all honesty I can't say I was disappointed as I knew it would fall pretty flat. Not to say that Black Ops II is a bad game, because it isn't its very decent. The single player experience was pretty stale, it was pretty much the same thing I saw in Black Ops 1 and Modern Warfare 3. The main story was pretty short, and despite all the hooplah about important choices effecting the outcome they really didn't. Other than a few dialogue changes. One thing that seemed better though was that it felt like they finally put a cap on the infinite re-spawning enemies. While the story and voice acting are definitely good there are still some very tongue in cheek kind of moments. (Spoilers!) Like charging a double barreled tank on horseback??? really? Another bit that left much to be desired were the side missions with the main story. While I could see that the developers really tried to mesh in a real time strategy feel to it in the end you'll find yourself running and gunning as you would usually do.

The multiplayer was pretty much the same experience I've seen in past Call of Duty titles. With the most frustrating return being bad maps. All maps feel claustrophobic which really effects the overall game play. Instead of using teamwork and strategy to win the day, your reduced to camping or running around constantly only to hope that you come across someone while their backs are turned. The weapons load-out though has some nice new touches. Such as the ability to use more perks or add more attachments to your weapons. With that the leveling is pretty much the same as it was in Black Ops I. As you level higher you unlock more camo, weapons, care packages and so on. One thing that I really liked though was the ability to customize your own in-game gamertag. I've seen some very creative stuff while online. In the end is seems they did everything good, except the maps for multiplayer.

In the end it reach the hype around it and left me unsatisfied. The Zombies bit of the game offered the most fun for me, but wasn't enough to make me like it more. Perhaps next time we'll see something better.
summary: More of the old, little of the new...

reviewText: as described, fast shipping

As a target shoot that competes, I love to play Wii games that help me refine me eye-hand coordination and response times.  That said, I was happy when Nintendo released their designs for the Wii Zapper, however, something bothered me.  The trigger was in the front while the grip was in the back.  This goes against most firearm setups as most target shooters place the grips in the front while the trigger is in the back.  This way, it feels more natural using your dominant hand as the trigger hand otherwise if you put it in reverse you either are forced to use your non-dominant hand or flip the hands around and are forced to keep the firearm pressed against your chest to keep your eyes down the sights.  The latter is an extreme no-no for anyone who has fired an actual firearm as the butt of the rifle should go against your shoulder, NOT your chest.

That said, firearm practitioners will find the Wii Zapper extremely non-ergonomic and somewhat cumbersome.  Anyone who has not fired a rifle will not notice the difference and adapt.  It is understandable why the Wii Remote must be placed in front since the forward laser needs a clear line of sight, however, it takes away from the feel of the zapper.  I bought the Zapper and quickly purchased the Nyko Perfect Shot as it feels more natural as a sidearm than the Zapper as a rifle or carbine.

This is not to say that the Zapper is not worth getting.  Link's crossbow training is very useful at practicing your usage of a standard Wii Remote and Nunchuck as it is with the Nyko Perfect Show.  I use my Perfect Shot on Link's Crossbow Training every now and then to improve my reaction time as well as eye-hand coordination.  The game hosts several excellent exercises to maximize efficiency with any firearm-type Wii device so it is worth paying the money over.

All in all, the game makes the Zapper, not the other way around.  Get the game but get the Nyko Perfect Shot to compliment the game.
summary: Fun Game, Zapper Feels Cumbersome and Lacks Ergonomics

reviewText: This product was a lot of hype and what got me about it was that the simplest things couuld have been adjusted and it would have made this a better system.

I feel the need to disclose my credentials before giving you my review.  I'm an avid gamer.  I own a gaming PC, PS3, 360, Wii, PSP, 3DS, and IPAD.  I play every genre that is out there:  MMO, single-player RPG, FPS, racing, 3rd person adventure, puzzles, casual games, etc...even kid's games.  The reason I tell you this is because I think I have played enough games, across enough platforms to be able to intelligently discuss and compare various games.  As far as MMO's are concerned, SWTOR has a lot of positive things going for it, and also has a lot of shortcomings.  I have been playing the game since the beta, so I have seen some of the improvements they made before release and have had an opportunity to have more time with the game than some other people may have had.

PROS

Where SWTOR really shines is in the story telling (class quests).  Being a fully voiced MMO and using cutscenes, the game presentation is great.  Stories for each of the classes are interesting and compelling.  The problem is it's greatest strength is also it's greatest weakness (see cons).  Most quests are the standard run-of-the-mill, kill this many of this and grab that many of that, so it won't win any awards for original gameplay.  The atmosphere of the entire game is very Star Wars.  There is something very satisfying playing as a Jedi or Sith and hearing the whoosh and buzz of a wielded light saber.  Combat feels more viseral than other MMOs I've played.  There are a wider range of player animations than typically seen in an MMO and the effects look good.  Sound design is also great and the orchestral scores are epic.  Planets like Tatooine and Hoth really make you feel like you have entered the Star Wars universe.  The game employs 4-player flashpoints that give players a chance to go thru a longer, dungeon type mini story that require players fulfilling various roles to complete objectives to get better loot (the old tank, dps, healer formula).  If the game was a single player RPG or even a local coop game this would all be great but when a game is advertised as an MMO people have certain expectations, well this is where the game falls short.  Another interesting mechanic to the game is that you get your own crew and a starship.  As your class storyline progresses, you will be introduced to NPCs that will become your companions.  These companions actually gather the mats for your crafting and do the crafting of your items.  You also get to take one companion with you everywhere you go.  Each companion has their own class so you can choose to take your healer, tank , or dps companion along with you on quests.  There are also rail style starship missions that act as a welcome diversion from the normal MMO grind.  These type of innovations are headed down the right path and have the potential to set the game apart from it's competitors.  As part of the competitive multiplayer aspects of the game, there are three warzones that players can participate in which are variants of capture the flag and capturing and holding certain areas on a map.  Being someone who enjoys all types of games and gameplay, I am content in playing the game and can keep myself occupied by playing every aspect of the game to it's fullest.  However, if you are the type of player that only likes to do 'battlegrounds' or questing, etc. and focuses only on one aspect of the game, there may not be enough content to keep you engaged for very long.

CONS

Being a story driven MMO forces the game to be fairly linear, this hurts grouping and reduces the feeling of having an open world to explore as you wish.  While having a variety of planets to visit, each planet is geared towards a particular level range so once played there is no reason to return and revisit a planet.  Also, there seems to be very little variation in the climate or terrain of each planet so each planet can be quickly reduced to the flat desert planet or fissure ridden ice planet if you get my drift.  And the part that falls flat and will disappoint hardcore MMO fans...end of game content.  End game content is lacking.  Leveling is fairly easy and quick in the game so unless you plan on playing the game to experience all the various storylines of the different classes you will probably get bored pretty quick. Armor models for high level gear are absolutely awful.  Being an artist myself I wonder who got the job of designing the clothing in this game.  You'll find yourself reaching to get the better gear for the stats only, not because the better gear actually also looks cooler. Despite the novel approach to crafting, there are not enough schematics or compelling schematics to engage you in the crafting process.  Most gear you can make for your level is lower quality than you can find.

I could go on much longer about the pros and cons of this game, but then I would never finish this review.

In summary, SWTOR has advanced the MMO genre in it's presentation and the addition of a strong story telling element, however, the implementation of these aspects caused some of the traditional aspects of MMOs to suffer.  I think the game has a lot of potential, but it will be interesting to see how Bioware and EA handle the MMO in the upcoming months to see if they can tweak the formula and evolve the game to the point where things begin to mesh better.  I am enjoying the game at the moment myself but hardcore MMO fans may get bored with this one quickly.  If I reviewed this game after only playing a character to level 30 or so I probably would have given it 5 stars, but it's clear that the crafting system and end game content are too weak to sustain most people's attention on a long term basis.  I think it's a game worth experiencing, but the decision is whether to give it a go now, or wait until they add more end game content and hopefully tweak the crafting system.

I would say that the Sonic Drift 2 borrowed the level names from the Sega Genesis Sonic The Hedgehog 2 and Sonic The Hedgehog 3 games. I highly recommend this game to anyone that still have their Sega Game Gear System.

I blame the manual for the difficulty issue. You should not always focus fire on the first ship. Thinking that this is always the proper thing to do would give one the impression that the game has thrown you into unwinnable circumstances by the time you get to the second system. All ships in the fleet contribute to overall performance including evasion. If you can hardly land any hits on the big tough ship in front, focus on any disposable peons behind it first. Then it will typically be much easier to deal with. Most early battles are all about dodging, waiting for the enemy to fire a barrage rather than a normal shot and then following up with your own and backing off until you can get dodge back up.

Anyway, I'll kick the review off with what I didn't like: Space battles are ugly. I mean real ugly. They should have gone with 2D here rather than opt for polygons since battles are quite literally one dimensional anyway. You still get that Front Mission sense of satisfaction watching your attacks initiate and seeing them smack into the enemy but focusing on 2D with a pleasing aesthetic rather than 3D on the DS would have made for a much more satisfying experience I think. Especially since the game is technically one-dimensional.

Yes, 1D. The only thing that you really control spatially is the distance between two fleets composed of up to 5 capital ships each (if you have the speed advantage). The 1D factor is actually not really a negative. It really doesn't need to be more complicated since much of the game is prep and strategy anyway. Tactics are more about when to come out of your dodge status to open fire and at what range so far (I'm not up to fighters or the need to really kill off the other guy's crew yet).

Like most ginoromous galaxy games, planets are by and large not very interesting outside of the conversations to be had at the bar and the inventory at any shops that may or may not be present. Some planets are completely pointless beyond being a place to rest your crew and repair all damage. It's more of a system-to-system game than planet-to-planet game.

I'm about 10 hours in and the story shows promise, but the itch that this game really scratches for me is the slow build to ultimate power factor. I compare it to Suikoden not just because there are 100 characters you can find (who all contribute to your fleet of up to five capital ships in various ways but also because the fleet itself is much like the castle that slowly grows and evolves in Suikoden only minus all the store conveniences and Iron Chef-style competitions.

It's like Front Mission in the sense that the battles are a fairly similar although typically less complex experience and you really spend a lot of time tweaking and configuring the ships in your fleet. You actually build out the interior with modules that serve both strategic and tactical roles and weapons, fighters and boarding actions are all possibilities.

I pretty much bought this one just looking at the box. I got the sense that it wasn't a real high-budget experience but that I was going to dig the strategy/build-your-own-fleet factor of it and I wasn't disappointed.
summary: Suikoden + Front Mission + Crappy Visuals (not that hard - see review)

reviewText:
So, I just finished my second play through of the game yesterday, and have come to a number of conclusions about it.

First of all, I will say that the game is simply fun to play. Combat is quick, chaotic, and responsive with a lot of room for customization based on personal preference. Multiple strategies work and you must constantly change your approach based on the situation at hand, which keeps things interesting throughout. Outside of combat, exploration of the world is deeply satisfying as numerous secrets exist and the environment is vivid and brilliantly realized. In short, it is a pleasure to see all that it offers and does not feel like a resource-collection grind (which is really what it is).

The story, while convoluted, is steeped in history, science, and fantasy. The merging of real events and social issues with advanced yet retro steampunk technologies and fanatical religion combine to create an alternate reality (in fact, an infinite number of them) that challenges the player intellectually. The way the story is told, through character interactions, voxophones (audio recordings), kinetoscopes (short movies), flashbacks (and forwards, sideways) feels novel when taken together, although these individual elements are used countless times in other games. The main characters are developed with real emotions and actions that reflect them. Nothing I can think of feels cheap with the sole purpose of driving things in a certain direction dictated by the development team.

So, given these glowing recommendations where are my reservations?

The enemies, while varied, are for the most part not particularly ominous. The vast majority of them are men (and women) just like you. Unlike the twisted inhabitants of Rapture with their mutant powers and mutated forms, the foes you face in Columbia are not really scary. The threat is more from their sheer numbers than anything else. A few exceptions exist, and there are a few startling moments, such as in the warden's office, but I felt a distinct lack of dread for most encounters, which was not true for the earlier games.

Another (more significant) gripe for me is the main resource itself, which is money (Silver Eagles). This is vastly different, and less satisfying, than the resource system in prior games. Gone are little sisters and the choices you must make to harvest or save them for precious ADAM. Even worse, ADAM harvesting from a corpse is also gone. These provided some of the most memorable moments--protecting your little sister from enemies flocking from all directions while she painstakingly harvests ADAM from the corpse.

And this leads to my last issue--you have little choice in this game. Whereas in prior games, the choices you make throughout the game directly influence its conclusion; in Bioshock Infinite, everything is leading towards an inevitable conclusion. In fact, all of the major choices have already been made OUTSIDE OF THE ACTION OF THE GAME.

So, taken on its own, this is a great game. When compared to its predecessors, which is only natural given the fact that this is a series, I felt that a few things I wanted were missing.

Still, this game is worth your time and monetary investment. It's clear from the moment it starts that this game was a labor of love and a lot of hard work and creativity went into it.
summary: Excellent game play, great story telling, but...

This game contains lawn darts, horseshoes, volleyball, badminton, mini-golf, croquet, driveway basketball & beach side basketball.
I played w/a friend which helped, but only to laugh at it.
Pros:
-Good organized menus, choices of length of play & easy-hard level of AI
-9 Gorgeous mini golf holes in Aztec, haunted, Congo, Wild west, medieval, area 51, prehistoric themes. if these were real, I'd pay $20 to play a game easily of those 9 holes.
-Knows how hard/soft you're flicking wii remote in volleyball, mini golf, basketball
-Volleyball responds to perfect timing to character & ball distance almost like real life
-Lawn darts uses wind as variable
-Good sound effects even of things going by in the background
-Basketball has easy control
-You can "taunt" your friends by hitting the d pad which will make random cute sounds on THEIR remote to throw off their concentration.
-Options for left or right handed people
-you can hit the shuttle in badminton left/right/up/down swings

Cons:
-Lack of clear instructions or practice play, only 1 window quick text instructions for each game.
-Camera angles in badminton & volleyball is  high in the sky which makes it hard to know when ball/shuttle is coming to you. GAMES SHOULD ALWAYS BE FIRST PERSON LIKE WII SPORTS OR VERY CLOSE THIRD. THAT'S THE SECRET.
-Volleyball timing even on easy MUST BE PERFECT, must swing+B to pass & swing up & down perfect timing to characters to spike & hard to see when ball is at the right spot.
-your characters will hit out of bounds in volleyball & badminton, considering it doesn't say you are able to aim & you hae to be perfect to not miss, how do you get it out of bounds???
-Badminton swings are hard to choose from since shuttle so small, it's hard to get timing right.
-Bad drawing/cartoon details on players, dark/bland/washed out coloring
-With lack of enough background (no audience to see or hear), the games feel a bit slower/dull then they should.

Golf - That's the only good thing of this game was the mini golf course design. Almost all the wholes had cool things moving, or had a timing edge to it. Only the congo one was boring like any mini golf course today.

I played this 2 separate times on the same wii, once w/friend who rented from one place & that disc had MANY glitches like basketball (we could never get 1 basket) & bad camera angles in mini golf that would always point you in the wrong way & load times in golf so slow, I think a year went by (the disc was spotless). The next time I played alone rented from another place & w/AI I won easily in basketball & mini golf & the load times were quick.

I tried various mats and foam pads but none gave such a matching look as this mat for the Playseat (duh).  I am using it to prevent scratches of moving my Playseat on the hardwood.

Previous reviews indicated this mat slides on the bottom and not good for securing on hardwood. My order came and it's made to not slide at all. So apparently improvements were made.

In my case, I actually need it to slide on the bottom. It's on hardwood, but when not using it's placed on the side. When ready to put in use, I have to slide it in position. With non-slide bottom, the seat just slide off the mat. So I got four flat head (1" diameter) screws to secure the mat to the seat, and cover the flat head with round chair pads that can slide.

There are alternatives but they are usually not perfect fit or color matched.  A good mat are not cheap either. So if you are buying a good mat, this is worth serious consideration.

I bought this game when it was roughly $30. I don't regret it one bit. I played this game 3 times, roughly 25 hours each time. As far as I'm concerned, the best class is the Sentinel. You're pretty much ready for ANYTHING with that class. I didn't enjoy the planet scanning, mainly cause I'm very impatient, & that takes me out of the action. I'd dedicate like 30-60 minutes to planet scanning for minerals that you use to upgrade your stuff/moves. I like the fact that you can hold RB to assess the situation, decide what move you wanna use, who to focus your squad's aiming on, etc.

When it comes to weapons, once you get the Particle Beam, you don't really need any other Heavy Weapon after that. The thing is prolly the strongest weapon in the game, & you don't have to use minerals to unlock it like the other Heavy Weapons. I COULD play it again, but I don't have the patience to sit through the cutscenes that I've already seen lol. Other than my extreme lack of patience though, this game is DEFINITELY worth the money.

reviewText:
Like many other reviews for Vita memory cards, this one will revolve around the absurd pricing, which borders on extortion.  The Vita is a great value for the hardware you get, but it comes with a meager 4 GB chip.  A single AAA game download will fill that card up, meaning it's good for little more than save data for your hard-copy games and some small odds and ends.  Considering how crucial wireless downloads are to modern systems, especially handhelds, this just doesn't work.  And so you spend at least $100 on more memory, which eliminates any value the Vita price held.  Those who carry Sony's water will attempt to justify this as a necessary counter to the money lost on hardware sales, but hardware has lost money in this business for decades.  It's the software that is supposed to recoup the lost money, not crucial components that are left out of the box.

However, PlayStation Plus has eased this issue somewhat.  It's a $50 a year price tag, so there's more dough spent, but it's a very solid service that offers a number of cheap or even free games for download.  And many of these are AAA quality titles, including Uncharted, Little Big Planet, Disgaea 3, and so on.  There are some negatives to Plus, which don't really belong in this review, but an overpriced memory card becomes a decent value if you're scoring $100-$300 worth of quality downloads every year.  You could theoretically sign on to Plus and never pay for a single game directly, and always have something good to play.  Traditionalists are undoubtedly tearing their hair out at this idea, since you'll never "own" any of these titles, but for most gamers who play-and-discard, it would be a great money-saving strategy.  Obviously, this requires faith that Sony will keep making good games available for free to Plus members, so buyer beware.

In short: if you play the angles right, you can justify the absurd prices of these memory cards.  (Comparable products can be found for other devices in the $20-$30 range.)  Otherwise, you'll have to swallow your pride.  $250 for a Vita?  It's $350, at least, and maybe more if you're a pack rat.  If you can hold out, wait for price drops across the board.

I like the other games as well, and found I was pretty good at some of the shooting challenge... even though I have never done anything like that before.  The ducks always surprise you... and are a bit tricky.

The shape matching is a bit tricky - until your auto-reflexes kick in.

Doesn't frustrate younger players, fun to pick up and play a few rounds, but if you are super competitive -  move on.

This use to be a very good game full of depth.  They just did a massive change to the game, hoping to get some of the market share from WoW.  They tried to make it feel more "Star Warsy".  What they did was tear it apart.  It is no longer an RPG.  It's also not a first person, or third person shooter.  It really is nothing at all now.  For anyone that has ever played a decent shooter, you'd laugh at just how bad this is.  To speed up combat they just sped up the game.  Animations look terrible now. Crafting and entertaining basicly has been taken out.  They went from some 30 professions to 9 (7 if you take crafting and entertaining out).  A major reason this game was so enjoyable was that you could do anything you want.  Now, you're stuck into a profession darn near forever.  You can't mix and match like you use to...ext.

This game lost a lot of players after the combat upgrade a few months ago.  And, again they are leaving in droves.  I see this game getting shut down by early next year.  Don't put a lot of time (or any) into this game, it's about to go down the drain.
summary: Use to be a good game.

Republic Commando is a fun, albeit short, game.  When I heard it was being developed, I really wasn't interested -- the premise didn't enthuse me.  But after trying the demo, I was very impressed.  The squad-based play is simple, but effective, and the AI is very well done.  Aside from a few instances where I thought the AI should be behaving differently, your computer-controlled squadmates are very capable and realistic for non-human players.  In fact, during the few sequences in the game in which you are seperated from them, I felt...alone.  The lack of their presence was really felt in the flow of the game.  Very well done.  The gameplay is fast paced and exciting (though a bit short), the voice acting is superb, and I was surprised by how long into the game I was before dialog from the squadmates repeated -- there's enough of it that you'll play awhile before hearing a line repeated.  There's also a fair amount of humor in the game.  And the characters of your squadmates are also well done -- they each have a distinct personallity, which makes the game more enjoyable.  I finished the game tonight and am ready to start playing through it again.  A lot of fun.
summary: I had no interest in buying this...until I tried the demo

reviewText:
This game is a really decent Tennis game. And probably is also one of the hardest, at least for me. ;) LOL  I am just not too good at tennis. This game is ultra realistic allowing you to experience firsthand all of the intensity, emotion, and excitement of a real life tennis match. The moves are just like the actual real life counterparts. I originally bought this game just for the 3D aspect as I am a 3D nut and the 3D in ti=his game is super. It adds an element of gameplay that brings the realism up a notch. Not that it wasn't realistic enough already! The game allows yo to play as one of 25 top names in the sport. The game is very in depth. Allowing you to play out full matches and seasons! The game is almost too much for me as I guess I am just not too much of a tennis nut or maybe it is that I am just not coordinated enough for it:) LOL either way, this game sure does deliver! And if you are not much of a tennis player, such as myself, then you can expect a serious learning curve. All in all I would have to say that this game delivers and in a BIG way!

Do you love tennis, do you own a PS3? If you answered yes to those,then you NEED this game! ANDm if your TV is 3D then you will be really impressed!
summary: A GREAT tennis game that has all the realism one could ever expect out of a game played on a TV and then some!!

reviewText: If you like well told stories involving heavy highschool drama, with a nice slice of time-travel sci-fi, there is no game I recommend more. Beautiful game with an amazing soundtrack, characters I will remember forever (Chloe in particular, thank you once again Ashly Burch), and a powerful story. Don't get me wrong, the game isn't perfect. The animations are somewhat limited, voices aren't always synced, and a few lines are nothing but cheesy. That said I promise this will be an amazing experience for you, so long as you can sit through a 15ish hour adventure (point and click) game. Expect lots of drama, sci-fi references and call-outs, and expect to cry a few times
summary: If you like well told stories involving heavy highschool drama

reviewText:
I loved Demon and Dark Souls games and I actually paid $59 for Dark Souls 2 when it came out ( I never buy new games ). My expectation were very high and tell you the truth the game itself is awesome, I played the game 3 times and I invested over 150 hours in to it.
I will probably revisit Dark Souls 2 in the future but for not now I am done with it. In my opinion Dark Souls 2 does not have as good player vs player as does Dark Souls and that's why I played Dark Souls for well over 1500 hours and I'm already done with Dark Souls 2.
If there is another Souls game in the future I would wait before paying full price.

We bought these covers for our Wii controllers in order that everyone in our family can play our Wii at the same time, and each person can have his or her own colored controller.  Sure stops us from fighting over whose individual Wii controller is whose because of the different colors.  I agree with another reviewer that they are somewhat hard to put on, so plan on them being there semi-permanently.  Another good investment from Amazon that will last for a long, long time.

The PlayStation 4 itself is a nice console.  It is not perfect as one may read.  The Dashboard aka "Home Screen", is very, very convoluted.  For example can be difficult to navigate and find something one is looking for.  Everything is buried "sub menu's".  Which can be time consuming, and annoying.

If you haven't heard by now.  It is slighlty "stronger" than its main competitor the Xbox One.  Generally seeing 120p better in Resolution.  But ultimately for a gamer it comes down to the Software (Games).

Before you go off saying "he never bought it" just go to my profile and go to my PS4 version where it is verified.
Now to the review:
So, it's that time of year again. Whether you are plan on getting the new call of duty or not, you know about it. You know that there are the fanboys who ordered it ten years ago, and you know there are the haters who insistently say that it is going to be terrible. Personally, after Ghosts, I was one of the haters. I thought that this game would be just like the others again, just FURTHER IN THE FUTURE, which nobody wanted. I changed my mind a couple of weeks ago after seeing the multiplayer reveal. Sure, this isn't the revolutionary game which is so bold, that everyone has to have it. This game is different. It is different from previous Call of Duty's, and it is different from any game you have ever played.
What makes it unique?
You may be thinking a lot of talk, and no walk. Well, the only place i'm walking to with this game is my couch. Advanced warfare is a bold step in the right direction. Whether it is the new movements presented with the exo skeleton in multiplayer, or the new HUI. Advanced Warfare blends in the new and shiny into smooth movements, almost as if you have been playing with the exo skeleton for a few years.
Why only 4 stars?
I don't believe any game is perfect, and there are still a lot of doubts in my head with Advanced Warfare. I think that four starts suits this game well.
I am one person who will say that Black Ops 2 is the best Call of Duty to be made, and everyone has their own opinion. It is hard to tell, only having played this for an hour or two, whether this game will be right up there. I definitely see the potential in it, and am looking forward to playing it for the next year until the NEW one comes out. This is how the system works, but I am convinced this year is going to be fun.
If you are still on edge about it, I will be uploading some gameplays to my Youtube channel. Just search Gandalf The Teal, and it should come up. If this review helped you, please give it an up vote. If you have any questions just ask them and I will respond.
summary: It is that time of year again

reviewText:
I like Rockstar games, but always find that even with their many in-game jokes, pop-culture references and social commentary, most of Rockstar's games are too difficult and too psychologically 'heavy' to play casually.

Saints Row on the other hand is just generally light hearted and more game-like than life-like, and "The Third" is by far the best of the series. Very fun, over the top, and off the wall with lots of good humor, some cheesy humor, and well balanced, fun, and interesting missions that are not too difficult, though some are challenging. It is a pick up and play delight with wonderful customization options.

This is a must have for adult gamers who enjoy madcap violence and mayhem

reviewText:
I've always been a fan of sim games, but never used my previous portable consoles (Gameboy, GBA, etc.) for anything but Pokemon. Maybe that would've been different if I'd known about the Harvest Moon series!

Recently, I have been able to play Harvest Moon 1 and 2 on an emulator. I loved them! I looked through the reviews for all Harvest Moons since, and saw that this one was a re-release due to poor feedback from its predecessor (Islands of Happiness, or something?). If that isn't an impressive response from a developer, I don't know what is.

This game isn't just cute--it requires a bit of brain power and time management, too. To me, there is nothing worse than a game that you can play on autopilot. Organization, forethought, and awareness are essential to obtaining the best results on your farm and with the villagers. This HM makes you think!

I actually bought Rune Factory 4 with my 3DS, thinking that RF4 would be a "replacement" for Harvest Moon: Sunshine Islands. Nope! I keep coming back to this game, and will continue coming back to this series, so long as Natsume keeps up the great work.

This game is very underrated, and it's a shame because it is one of the most creative and fun games SEGA has put out in the last years of their Dreamcast remnants. Originally a Dreamcast game, it is a very fun and entertaining cyber-punk techno-retro-futuristic adventure game that puts the player into a awesome world. For its low price, it is a great value that every SEGA anthusiast must own.

Honestly, this game is simply outstanding.  If you like Dark Souls, what are you waiting for?  This game is faster paced and has tighter controls.  Admittedly, Dark Souls has a more expansive world, but this game's world is still equally as immersive.  From the sound quality to the artistic and graphical prowess, this game's quality standard is excellent.

If you do not like difficult games, this will make you break things and pull your hair out.  The likes of Contra is still more difficult, but few modern games are this challenging.  Though the game is challenging, it is always fair.  When I die, I saw it coming.

Who is this for?
-RPG lovers
-Anyone wanting a challenge
-Action adventure fans
-Hardcore gamers
-Casual gamers who want one game to play for a long time

Who is this not for?
-You play for the story
-Those who do not enjoy challenge
-You only like FPS
-Offended by violence and dark themes

I do think the themes are too dark for younger players.  For example, you can collect and consume umbilical cords in this game...  Lines aren't quite crossed for older players, but this is not a game for a 12 year old, in my opinion.

Concerning the special edition extras, the soundtrack is very well done and the art book is a quality feeling hardback booklet.  The Bloodborne art book feels much higher quality than the art book that came with the Dark Souls special edition.  The tin case with this Bloodborne edition is also a very nice touch.  This package was worth my money.

Overall, this will likely be my game of the year, by a very large margin.
Awesome game.

It does not go without saying that Super Mario Galaxy was a huge breakthrough for the Nintendo Wii seven years ago (Yes. It's that long ago now!). Despite that, it was as equally surprising to see a sequel come aboard three years later. For the first time ever, there's a direct sequel to a 3D Mario game on the same console. Considering how much of an event each game in the series was, this was an unexpected treat! Fast-forward to the day I got the game, it did not disappoint!

Admittedly, there were a couple things that I found concerning. The game starts off with this storybook-like opening. In it, Mario goes through this little 2D level, and on the way through, he comes across the silver Luma that grants him his spin-attack and other Lumas that tell Mario they can be used as Sling Stars to fling Mario across the sky. The problems I have with this is that it doesn't bring in the same engaging tone the first game had, and it also plays out everything as if the first game never happened. This further goes on when other returning characters from Galaxy 1 meet each other "for the first time" (and Rosalina, arguably the most important character in the first game, is gone here). It bothers me considering this is supposed to be a SEQUEL. Heck, even on the Wii Menu, Mario shouts "Super Mario..GALAXY!" completely dismissing the "2". And this isn't even a recycled voice clip! This was re-recorded for this SEQUEL. What's going on here?

Labels aside, Super Mario Galaxy 2 is jam-packed with creativity just like its predecessor! If you've played the original, you'll be able to dive right in, because the game functions almost identically to before. You use the Wii Remote and Nunchuck to have Mario move around gorgeous environments as he runs, jumps, swings his fists, and RIDES YOSHI! Yep! Yoshi joins in on the fun this time around in some levels, and he's not the only sidekick; Luigi is back and ready to kick some! You don't even need to collect 120 Stars to unlock him! No matter which brother you play as, though, there's plenty to adore and explore.

There are fewer Stars to collect in each galaxy you come across, but that actually gets balanced out by the slightly more galaxies there are in total. And boy are these galaxies FUN! Longtime Mario fans can already expect to fall in love with the imaginative designs these worlds are composed of, but the overall result is positively exhilarating for everybody. There are levels of all shapes and sizes, with casts of themes and enemies, as well as loads of stuff Mario can do to move on. There are galaxies where everything is giant, where Mario guides Chain Chomps moving along flip panels, where Mario can dig through the ground, where evil clones chase him, where Yoshi is used to dash as quickly as Sonic, and the list goes on. This is just a small fraction of what the game has to offer!

Heck, even when you beat the game, there's still a lot of content left over for you to finish during a post-game journey. Hidden Stars are everywhere, and there is even a gauntlet of levels that will likely put your skills to the test. I'm not going to go too deep into this subject, but let's just say that the game manages to squeeze in a whopping 242 Stars to collect in total, and that can only take place after beating the game once!

Anyway, what exactly will Mario be equipped with as he sprints along planets joyfully? Well, along with some levels containing Yoshi, there will be a number of power-ups Mario can use to help add some spice to the adventure. Some of the power-ups return from the original Mario Galaxy, such as the Bee Mushroom, which gives Mario a silly bee costume and allows him to buzz in the air, the Boo Mushroom, turning Mario into a ghost, and the Spring Mushroom, which has Mario bounce as a spring. This time around, though, we also get the Cloud Flower, which allows Mario to seriously create his own cloud platforms, and a Rock Mushroom that turns him into a boulder. Yoshi also gets a few powers of his own, causing him to run, float like a balloon, and glow like a light bulb.

While we're on the topic of assistance, does anybody remember the 2-Player mode in the original Galaxy? That thing was a joke. That was really my only real problem with the game, but it irks me nevertheless. Mario Galaxy 2 brought the mode back, but this time, it's kinda more fleshed out. Probably not by much to justify it as an amazing feat, but it's still worthy to note that there have only been improvements. The second player now has a Luma character, and can not only stun enemies and pick up Star Bits lying around, but he/she can also pick up coins and mushrooms, kill enemies, flip switches, and activate checkpoints.

Like the game before it, Super Mario Galaxy 2 is masterpiece, despite some quirks I couldn't help but notice. Whether or not you own the original Super Mario Galaxy, this sequel is wholeheartedly recommended. Personally, I prefer getting the first game if I had to judge, but let's be real here: There's no reason why you wouldn't buy both. They're both amazing quality platformers :P

I have played Call of Duty with this keyboard for about 4 years now. It works great. I like blue and purple better than red because they are brighter. But the keyboard runs perfectly on Vista anyway. During gameplay about once every 2 months it will shut off all control so you have to unplug it and replug it in(I think it is because of hitting too many keys at once) it can be annoying. It also has 1 Mic. and 1 headset jack and 2 USB ports. Some headset/mic. cabels don't fit well, but they work fine. It is a well made keyboard and will last for a few more years. I am very happy with the purchase.

Update 3-22-14: This keyboard still works like new! It has been ~8 years now, and 3..or 4? computers. Don't install the software it comes with on win7! The software sometimes causes the keyboard to reboot randomly. Also, after 8 years, some of the rubber on the gamepad has started to wear, but I have probably pressed the W key about 20,000,000 times, probably totaling 2,000 hours, so this is acceptable.

I would buy a new one today if this one broke.

When talk of his daughter's supposed death seems to resurface, Sam Fisher decides he's tired of hiding, and the people who have betrayed him - the very same people who have ordered him around throughout his career as Splinter Cell - are all going to pay.

While that doesn't sound particularly original, it's certainly entertaining. The plot unfolds more like an episode of 24 than a plodding Tom Clancy novel. Twists abound, and people aren't always who they seem to be. The plot also gives some very interesting insight into Sam Fisher's character, as the silent badass becomes more human. You really get a sense of who, and what he's fighting for, and it's a real treat toward the end-game when his philosophies on revenge, duty, and trust really come to the surface.

The campaign is short - five hours short - but it's very fun, and even finds some strength in it's brevity. After a brief introductory sequence in Malta, Sam spends the rest of his time lurking around Washington, D.C., visiting various locations to unravel a treasonous conspiracy.

Perhaps "lurking" isn't the right word, though. Stealth elements in Conviction have been stripped down to the essentials, crouching in shadows, and watching enemy patrols for the right time. Beyond that, Splinter Cell plays more like an action game with an emphasis on keeping to the shadows. Players can swiftly take down enemies with the push of a button, and if things get out of hand, they're armed to the teeth, or if they're a bit more sneaky, they can make a quick getaway with one of the new gadgets.

Thankfully, even with the absence of some of the older features, Ubisoft has added in quite a few awesome new gameplay mechanics. The first, and most important is Mark and Execute. The player can pick out a number of enemies, and with the tap of a button, quickly dispatch them all, making it easy to get passed overwhelming patrols. But, it's not like it's a win button either, you have to get a melee kill to charge up your Mark and Execute meter, which pretty much perfectly balances out the new mechanic. The second notable new feature is Last Known Position. Upon being spotted, a silhouette of Sam will appear so you can tell where the guards thought you were last. This makes it easier to escape, or even set up an ambush.

There are some spots that change up the formula, and they can be quite entertaining. Chasing a conspirator around the Washington Monument, and, in a throwback to the old style of Splinter Cells, a sequence where you have to maneuver around an environment completely undetected. There are some pretty superb moments beyond that which I won't spoil, but there are some moments which don't work as well. Interrogations are brutally satisfying, but they serve to slow things down quite a bit, and are little more than slightly interactive cut-scenes.

The campaign is quite good as long as you're not expecting a lengthy adventure. The game has changed, Sam Fisher has changed, and in most part, it's for the better.

A Co-Op campaign was disappointingly absent from Splinter Cell: Double Agent, a letdown indeed after its memorable debut in Chaos Theory. Co-Op is back in full force in Conviction, however, in the form of The Prologue, which might just be the best of Splinter Cell: Conviction's three main pillars of game modes.

The Prologue doesn't have as much of an emphasis on story, but it does rather well in leading up to Sam's rampage as seen in the Campaign, and the character development is actually pretty great. Archer, a Third Echelon agent, and Kestrel, a Russian agent working for Voron (an international Third Echelon equivalent) must form an alliance to track down some stolen weaponry. Oh, and there's an awesome twist ending.

In terms of the gameplay, things remain pretty much the same as in the Campaign, however, working together on coordinated strikes against guards is a lot of fun, and, as mentioned before, co-op Mark and Executes are pretty insane, allowing you to clear out quite a few guards with a little bit of team work.

The Co-Op in Conviction is tons of fun, and in my opinion, the best mode the game has to offer. The story is well told, if simple, and the gameplay really lends itself to a co-op experience.

Deniable Ops is the last piece of the Conviction equation, and it doesn't totally stack up to the rest of the game's offerings. It's essentially a quick-play mode for one or two players in which an objective must be completed on one of the maps from the Prologue (as well as one additional one exclusive to Deniable Ops). There's Hunter, in which players must take down a certain number of enemies, Last Stand, where they must defend an EMP against waves of attackers, Infiltration, which requires players to take down guards without being detected, and Stand Off, Conviction's only adversarial multiplayer mode.

Of these, Hunter is the only one that really works, since the core gameplay (as in guard-killing fun) holds up just fine. Last Stand and Infiltration don't work as well because they require either all-out gunplay, or total stealth respectively, which goes against the game's natural balance of the two. Stand Off is a simple spy vs. spy deathwatch, the twist being that A.I. guards litter the map. For the most part, it works pretty well, but it's nothing outstanding.

While it's disappointing that there's no Spies vs. Mercenaries mode, Deniable Ops does the trick when it comes to quick, pick-up-and-play Splinter Cell action, just don't expect anything deep.

Campaign, Prologue, and Deniable Ops are held together by PEC Challenges, which can be completed across any of the game modes. The challenges range from simply escaping from a heated situation, to more whacky stuff like killing a guard by throwing another guard at him. These challenges award points which can be used for upgrading weapons and gadgets (for use across all game modes), and uniforms (only usable in Deniable Ops). These challenges actually offer a decent incentive for replay value, and outfitting your gear quickly becomes addicting.

Conviction's production values aren't stellar, but they get the job done. The graphics run on the now-dated Unreal 2 engine, although it does well all things considered. Lighting effects continue to impress, and the art-style is quite good, however, close inspection of pretty much anything in the game will reveal how low-tech it is. The sound department is decent, too. Voice acting is hit or miss, with Michael Ironside's gravelly Sam Fisher being a highlight, as always. The music is quite good, and really sets the tone for sneaking, or all-out confrontations. Sound effects can get repetitive, but for the most part the game does its job in looking, and sounding fine, but there's nothing amazing here.

From Conviction's Campaign, and Co-Op Campaign offerings, you're play time will probably clock in at around 12 hours, but Deniable Ops, and PEC Challenges can chew up a lot of time as well. The individual pieces of the package won't provide a whole lot of mileage, but combined, this game definitely has the replay value to justify a purchase.

Splinter Cell: Conviction is a very hit or miss game when it comes to everything from gameplay mechanics, to production values. The game is certainly not without its flaws, but the good ultimately outweighs the bad making Conviction a game worth checking out.
summary: Sam Fisher's Rampage is Thoroughly Enjoyable
